mil5.4.7:0.1_0: The Simile of the Making Hand
mil5.4.7:1.1_0: “Are you skilled in Nāgadatta; or not, or the result of good deeds?”
mil5.4.7:1.2_0: “Great king, those who are skillful and unskillful, blameworthy, results in suffering, and results in happiness.”
mil5.4.7:10.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was born a human being, he had a barley called Devadatta because of his awakening.
mil5.4.7:11.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was ready in the best city, he had a kingdom, his menstrumental ladies, and he reached the peak of awakening.
mil5.4.7:12.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was a human being, he had a king named Sāgata, a wheel of the Teaching, or even the whole of Devadatta.
mil5.4.7:13.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was walking along a street, a greedy elephant, a wild elephant, or a wild elephant, he would enter the sure path with all seven submit took away.
mil5.4.7:14.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was attached to the realm of the aristocrat vassals, all of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics present all those who was devoted to him as well.
mil5.4.7:15.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta had a son with a land of the Cetīs, he put down a son with both hands and feet, and ate them on the ground.
mil5.4.7:16.1_0: Furthermore, Devadatta had a native spirit called Bodhi. There, too, when he was still not a native spirit, all around, and both on occasions.
mil5.4.7:17.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was a gentleman, she had a friend of mine, five hundred sages, even sixty jealousy, degrations, and even levels.
mil5.4.7:18.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was a caravan of five hundred carts, all of them lived on wagons.
mil5.4.7:19.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was called Bodhi, the king of mountains, was his deer, and he gave both portion and serenity.
mil5.4.7:2.1_0: “Even when you speak with a dragon,
mil5.4.7:2.2_0: ‘See, being exclusively happy—all have exclusively dark, unskillful qualities.’
mil5.4.7:2.3_0: Furthermore, Devadatta’s awakening is fame and renown after fame, which his awakening is even more splendid and bountiful.
mil5.4.7:2.4_0: When Devadatta had the king’s son commended the king’s son Tissa and the high priest’s son Tagarasikhī, his wife attained to fruit, and fame, his awakening, and the mango grove.
mil5.4.7:20.1_0: Furthermore, in a decline there was a king named General Sīha, the king followed his awakening, and he eventually arrived at all times.
mil5.4.7:21.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was a brahmin called Bhaṇḍu, he had a beggar.
mil5.4.7:22.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was King Brahmadatta, he had a son called Brahmadatta, who he has had a son of his father, a son of the Sakyans, and who possessed the power of Devadatta,
mil5.4.7:23.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was a king called Mahāvijita’s son, he had a son called Devadatta, who Uttarād him, who had a son of his own head,
mil5.4.7:24.1_0: and even today, too, they were reborn in the Sakyan clan.
mil5.4.7:24.2_0: The Buddha realized the whole world,
mil5.4.7:24.3_0: “Sir, what have I done to you like a dragon?”
mil5.4.7:25.1_0: “That’s just a lot, great king, you have made all reality.”
mil5.4.7:25.2_0: “Sir, what are the dark result of dark and bright results only with dark and bright results?”
mil5.4.7:25.3_0: “Great king, no skilled in what is unskillful and skilled in the result of deeds, not in Devadatta.
mil5.4.7:25.4_0: Now, the being intent on awakening gives rise to its fruit.
mil5.4.7:25.5_0: When Devadatta is authorityd by authority, a transformed by protection, making merit with white lotuses, as well as those ascetics and brahmins.
mil5.4.7:25.6_0: He obtains a result to be cut off by continued existence.
mil5.4.7:25.7_0: Who should be tamed, great king, relying on giving this gift?
mil5.4.7:26.1_0: But in you say that the being intent on awakening is like this. And when the host of Joyful Gods, you’ve passed, there was no coming to be of a very long time.
mil5.4.7:26.2_0: The Buddha has gained this simile of the human being. He will remember it as a god or Māra and Brahmā.
mil5.4.7:27.1_0: He was not a friend of mine.
mil5.4.7:28.1_0: He was the seventh time, great king. He had many hundreds of thousands of senior monks. His father, brother, sister, relatives, or clan, and friends. Being afraid of wrongdoing, and fond of the training.
mil5.4.7:28.3_0: In the same way, all of them transmigrate.
mil5.4.7:28.4_0: Devadatta. He then liable to fall apart and fall into the Great Hell. Noble One, liable to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in the Great Hell. He shows the same teaching, a hundred thousand coins. Nor does he for seven years, aiming at division, he makes an effort with situational awareness, and heaven.
mil5.4.7:28.5_0: “It’s good, Sir, that you should repeat what I have said.”
mil5.4.7:3.1_0: Furthermore, when King Mahāvijita was all these great foes,
mil5.4.7:4.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was no human folk. And when Devadatta had a female monkey, he won’t be able to cause a human being.
mil5.4.7:5.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was a human being, held against him—the power of that, the dragon king, then sat on the ground. And he drove across that elephant named Devadatta.
mil5.4.7:6.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was walking along a forest grove, he drooping them with a harness, and Devadatta experienced Devadatta, got carried away on all sides, only a frank.
mil5.4.7:7.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was finished, the King of Kāsī, he had a liquor called Devadatta, his being intent on awakening, which he cutting off his hands, and said to him,
mil5.4.7:8.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was a human being, he said to Nanda,
mil5.4.7:9.1_0: Furthermore, when Devadatta was a human being, he was a king named Pajjota. He had a dragon king called Devadatta, even more splendid and bountiful.
